citations.narrative:
The facility did not fulfill the outlined schedule in their program of veterinary care for the vaccination of two dogs, and fecal
testing of one additional dog. The program of veterinary care (PVC) states fecal tests will be performed on annual basis,
with distemper and parvovirus vaccine boosters administered every three years. Bella and Maggie were due to receive
their DHPP boosters on 8/14/23, but these vaccines had not been given for the 2023 calendar year. Additionally, Bella
and Nemo were due for their fecal tests in 2023, but no fecals were performed. The facility reached out to their
veterinarian’s office during the inspection to check if the records for these tests and vaccines were available, in the event
the facility’s copies had been misplaced. After speaking with the vet’s office, they confirmed these actions items had not
been completed.
Following a program of veterinary care's directives for preventative care ensures the animals are adequately protected
from dangerous diseases and illnesses and safeguards their overall health status. The facility must follow the approved
program of veterinary and ensure all preventatives and sample testing are completed according to the approved
schedule.
Correct by February 9, 2024.

Bags of bedding used for ducks were stacked and stored directly on the floor and against the walls in a storage shed.
Additionally, two other instances were identified during the inspection where bedding was inappropriately stored. One
opened bag of bedding used for a duck receiving medical care was sitting beside the duck’s primary enclosure on the
floor. Elsewhere, six bags of bedding used for ducks and macaws were stored on the floor in the outdoor area where
macaws and ducks were housed.
Storing food supplies away from the walls and off the ground helps mitigate opportunities for vermin infiltration, while
supporting efficient cleaning and monitoring practices for all supplies stored, before they are dispensed out to the avian
species on-hand.
Supplies of food, including food supplements, bedding, and substrate must be stored in a manner that protects against
deterioration, spoilage, contamination, and vermin infestation. The supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the
walls, to allow cleaning underneath and around the supplies. All food must be stored in a manner that prevents
deterioration of its nutritive value.
Correct by January 26, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
